articles.headline: In Russia, a Military Buildup That Can’t Be Missed
articles.snippet: Russia’s massing of tanks and infantry along its southwestern border with Ukraine was meant to send a message, analysts say.
articles.abstract: Russia’s massing of tanks and infantry along its southwestern border with Ukraine was meant to send a message, analysts say.
articles.lead_paragraph: MASLOVKA, Russia — Deep in a pine forest in southern Russia, military trucks, their silhouettes blurred by camouflage netting, appear through the trees. Soldiers in four-wheel-drive vehicles creep along rutted dirt roads. And outside a newly pitched tent camp, sentries, Kalashnikovs slung over their shoulders, pace back and forth.

articles.headline: Another Unlikely Pandemic Shortage: Boba Tea
articles.snippet: The popular drink’s main ingredient, tapioca pearls, could soon be in short supply because of delays in unloading cargo ships from Asia.
articles.abstract: The popular drink’s main ingredient, tapioca pearls, could soon be in short supply because of delays in unloading cargo ships from Asia.
articles.lead_paragraph: A panic erupted on the West Coast this week. Over a drink.

articles.headline: Oath Keeper Pleads Guilty and Will Cooperate in Jan. 6 Riot Inquiry
articles.snippet: The plea by a member of the far-right extremist group the Oath Keepers was the first to be entered publicly by any of the more than 400 people who have been charged so far in the attack.
articles.abstract: The plea by a member of the far-right extremist group the Oath Keepers was the first to be entered publicly by any of the more than 400 people who have been charged so far in the attack.
articles.lead_paragraph: A member of the Oath Keepers militia who was charged in connection with the riot at the Capitol pleaded guilty on Friday and agreed to cooperate with the government — potentially against other members of the far-right extremist group.

articles.headline: Biden Wavers on Restricting Refugee Entry
articles.snippet: The Biden administration will for now maintain a historically low refugee cap. But after a widespread backlash from Democrats, the White House said it would raise refugee admissions in May.
articles.abstract: The Biden administration will for now maintain a historically low refugee cap. But after a widespread backlash from Democrats, the White House said it would raise refugee admissions in May.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The White House announced on Friday that President Biden would limit the number of refugees allowed into the United States this year to the historically low level set by the Trump administration, reversing an earlier promise to welcome more than 60,000 people fleeing war and persecution.
articles.byline: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Miriam Jordan

articles.headline: In a Spasm of Violence, Indianapolis Faces the Country’s Latest Mass Shooting
articles.snippet: The country grappled with yet another bloody rampage, only weeks after back-to-back mass shootings last month in Atlanta and Boulder, Colo.
articles.abstract: The country grappled with yet another bloody rampage, only weeks after back-to-back mass shootings last month in Atlanta and Boulder, Colo.
articles.lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS — He appeared in the parking lot after dark — a hooded figure with a gun who immediately began spraying bullets in every direction.
articles.byline: By Sarah Bahr, Mitch Smith and Campbell Robertson

articles.headline: Realtors Want to Sell You a Home. Their Trade Group Backs Evicting Others.
articles.snippet: The National Association of Realtors is advocating an end to a pandemic-era order meant to keep renters in their homes.
articles.abstract: The National Association of Realtors is advocating an end to a pandemic-era order meant to keep renters in their homes.
articles.lead_paragraph: Some of the same people in charge of selling you a home have sued to make it easier to evict people from one.

articles.headline: 100 Days Without Trump on Twitter: A Nation Scrolls More Calmly
articles.snippet: Democrats are breathing easier. Republicans are crying censorship. For all of the country’s news consumers, a strange quiet has descended after a four-year bombardment of presidential verbiage.
articles.abstract: Democrats are breathing easier. Republicans are crying censorship. For all of the country’s news consumers, a strange quiet has descended after a four-year bombardment of presidential verbiage.
articles.lead_paragraph: That soothing sound that Gary Cavalli hears emanating from Twitter these days? It is the sound of silence — specifically, the silence of former President Donald J. Trump.

articles.headline: One Way to Get People Off the Streets: Buy Hotels
articles.snippet: For homeless people, a place to live is life changing to a degree that almost no other intervention can provide.
articles.abstract: For homeless people, a place to live is life changing to a degree that almost no other intervention can provide.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The inside of the van was lined with plastic. The driver was masked and ready to go. There was a seat for just one passenger.

articles.headline: Throughout Trial Over George Floyd’s Death, Killings by Police Mount
articles.snippet: Since testimony in Derek Chauvin’s trial began on March 29, more than three people a day have died at the hands of law enforcement.
articles.abstract: Since testimony in Derek Chauvin’s trial began on March 29, more than three people a day have died at the hands of law enforcement.
articles.byline: By John Eligon and Shawn Hubler

articles.headline: Debating Exit From Afghanistan, Biden Rejected Generals’ Views
articles.snippet: Over two decades of war, the Pentagon had fended off the political instincts of elected leaders frustrated with the grind of Afghanistan. But President Biden refused to be persuaded.
articles.abstract: Over two decades of war, the Pentagon had fended off the political instincts of elected leaders frustrated with the grind of Afghanistan. But President Biden refused to be persuaded.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden used his daily national security briefing on the morning of April 6 to deliver the news that his senior military leaders suspected was coming. He wanted all American troops out of Afghanistan by Sept. 11, the 20th anniversary of the attacks on New York and the Pentagon.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper, Eric Schmitt and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: FedEx Gunman Bought 2 Rifles After Police Seized His Shotgun, Chief Says
articles.snippet: Brandon Hole, 19, had his shotgun taken away in March 2020 after his mother raised concerns about his mental state, records show. But he was able to legally make gun purchases just months later.
articles.abstract: Brandon Hole, 19, had his shotgun taken away in March 2020 after his mother raised concerns about his mental state, records show. But he was able to legally make gun purchases just months later.
articles.lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS — Brandon Hole, the 19-year-old man who the police say fatally shot eight people at a FedEx facility on Thursday night, legally purchased two semiautomatic rifles he used in the attack just a few months after the police seized a shotgun from him, the chief of the Indianapolis Metropolitan Police Department said on Saturday.
articles.byline: By Andrés R. Martínez, Mitch Smith, Alison Saldanha, Campbell Robertson and Ali Watkins

articles.headline: The Oscars Are a Week Away, but How Many Will Watch?
articles.snippet: TV ratings for awards shows have been in free fall, especially during the pandemic, and Hollywood doesn’t want the viewing public to toss its premier showcase into the entertainment dustbin.
articles.abstract: TV ratings for awards shows have been in free fall, especially during the pandemic, and Hollywood doesn’t want the viewing public to toss its premier showcase into the entertainment dustbin.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Neither intimate looks into stars’ living rooms nor scantily clad pop stars performing provocative hits have been able to stop audiences from tuning out award shows this year. The ratings for the Grammys were down by 53 percent. The Golden Globes plummeted by more than 60.
articles.byline: By Nicole Sperling and Brooks Barnes

articles.headline: Afghan Women Fear the Worst, Whether War or Peace Lies Ahead
articles.snippet: Whatever happens once the United States withdraws will not bode well for Afghan women. But even the gains made for them over the last 20 years have often been fleeting.
articles.abstract: Whatever happens once the United States withdraws will not bode well for Afghan women. But even the gains made for them over the last 20 years have often been fleeting.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Farzana Ahmadi watched as a neighbor in her village in northern Afghanistan was flogged by Taliban fighters last month. The crime: Her face was uncovered.
articles.byline: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Fatima Faizi and Najim Rahim

articles.headline: One America News Network Stays True to Trump
articles.snippet: A recent OAN segment said there were “serious doubts about who’s actually president,” and another blamed “anti-Trump extremists” for the Capitol attack.
articles.abstract: A recent OAN segment said there were “serious doubts about who’s actually president,” and another blamed “anti-Trump extremists” for the Capitol attack.
articles.lead_paragraph: Months after the inauguration of President Biden, One America News Network, a right-wing cable news channel available in some 35 million households, has continued to broadcast segments questioning the validity of the 2020 presidential election.

articles.headline: From boardroom to bedroom: New York’s empty office buildings and hotels may be ripe for conversion.
articles.abstract: Dark windows. Quiet lobbies. Hushed halls.
articles.lead_paragraph: Dark windows. Quiet lobbies. Hushed halls.

articles.headline: As New Police Reform Laws Sweep Across the U.S., Some Ask: Are They Enough?
articles.snippet: States have passed over 140 police oversight bills since the killing of George Floyd, increasing accountability and overhauling rules on the use of force. But the calls for change continue.
articles.abstract: States have passed over 140 police oversight bills since the killing of George Floyd, increasing accountability and overhauling rules on the use of force. But the calls for change continue.
articles.lead_paragraph: In February, Illinois enacted a law that rewrote many of the state’s rules of policing, and mandated that officers wear body cameras. In March, New York City moved to make it easier for citizens to sue officers. This month, the Maryland legislature — which decades ago became the first to adopt a Law Enforcement Officers’ Bill of Rights — became the first to do away with it.
articles.byline: By Steve Eder, Michael H. Keller and Blacki Migliozzi

articles.headline: CBS News Will Try to Reinvent Itself, Again
articles.snippet: In an interview as she prepares to step down as news division head, Susan Zirinsky said, “I feel I have given my entire soul into rebuilding this organization.”
articles.abstract: In an interview as she prepares to step down as news division head, Susan Zirinsky said, “I feel I have given my entire soul into rebuilding this organization.”
articles.lead_paragraph: In May 2020, a few months after “CBS Evening News” relocated from its longtime Manhattan home to Washington — a move that perplexed some producers and cost millions — the third-ranked newscast finally seemed to be finding a groove.
articles.byline: By Michael M. Grynbaum and John Koblin

articles.headline: In the Roaring Twenties, Ads Make a Comeback
articles.snippet: Subscriptions may be the rage, but businesses of all sorts are pouring money into advertising — digital most of all.
articles.abstract: Subscriptions may be the rage, but businesses of all sorts are pouring money into advertising — digital most of all.
articles.lead_paragraph: If you wanted to sound smart at a media business conference or sell your start-up over the last couple of years, you’d talk about the rise of digital subscriptions. Netflix and Spotify led the way in getting consumers to pay every month for their content, and The New York Times, The Washington Post and many others followed. By last week, everyone was hawking media subscriptions, from the owners of the SpongeBob SquarePants TV show ($5.99 a month) to the staid newswire Reuters ($35) to my friend Isaac who wanders aimlessly around New York ($7).

articles.headline: ‘God Knows What’s Going to Happen’: Minneapolis Braces for Verdict in Floyd’s Death
articles.snippet: Businesses boarded up and residents held their breath, fearing a repeat of last year’s unrest if the jury brings back a decision that the public sees as unjust.
articles.abstract: Businesses boarded up and residents held their breath, fearing a repeat of last year’s unrest if the jury brings back a decision that the public sees as unjust.

articles.headline: The Fed Faces Criticism as It Wades Into Climate and Equity Issues
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve is proudly politically independent. That makes key discussions around climate change and racial inequity a balancing act.
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve is proudly politically independent. That makes key discussions around climate change and racial inequity a balancing act.
articles.lead_paragraph: In mid-2019, Jerome H. Powell fielded a question from reporters that he often faced in those days: Were politics, and particularly a pressure campaign coming from Donald J. Trump’s White House to cut interest rates, influencing the Federal Reserve’s policy stance?

articles.headline: With ‘Knives Out’ Deal, Netflix Signals It’s in the Franchise Business
articles.snippet: The streaming gold rush of 2017-18, when Netflix scooped up big-name television creators, now seems to have migrated to the film world.
articles.abstract: The streaming gold rush of 2017-18, when Netflix scooped up big-name television creators, now seems to have migrated to the film world.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Hollywood let out a collective gasp this month when it was announced that Netflix had spent about $465 million to buy two sequels to the quirky surprise 2019 hit “Knives Out.”

articles.headline: Fleeing a Modern War, Syrians Seek Refuge in Ancient Ruins
articles.snippet: So many people have fled to Syria’s crowded northwest that families have settled in important archaeological sites. “We, too, have become ruins.”
articles.abstract: So many people have fled to Syria’s crowded northwest that families have settled in important archaeological sites. “We, too, have become ruins.”
articles.lead_paragraph: AL-KFEIR, Syria — As the sun set, children in dirty clothes and battered shoes herded sheep past the towering stone walls of a Byzantine settlement abandoned more than 1,000 years ago, leading them into an ancient cave nearby where the animals would spend the night.
articles.byline: By Ben Hubbard and Ivor Prickett

articles.headline: ‘We Were Left With Nothing’: Argentina’s Misery Deepens in the Pandemic
articles.snippet: The economy contracted by nearly 10 percent last year, and the country faces a reckoning with the I.M.F. over $45 billion in debts.
articles.abstract: The economy contracted by nearly 10 percent last year, and the country faces a reckoning with the I.M.F. over $45 billion in debts.
articles.lead_paragraph: Before the pandemic, Carla Huanca and her family were making modest but meaningful improvements to their cramped apartment in the slums of Buenos Aires.
articles.byline: By Peter S. Goodman and Daniel Politi
